member.summary: The game content cooking Keys. Use the same value for a game and DLC packages to support loading them by the build game. Use 0 to randomize it during building.

member.summary: If checked, the builds produced by the Game Cooker will be treated as for final game distribution (eg. for game store upload). Builds done this way cannot be tested on console devkits (eg. Xbox One, Xbox Scarlett).

member.summary: Disables shaders compiler optimizations in cooked game. Can be used to debug shaders on a target platform or to speed up the shaders compilation time.

member.summary: Enables shader debug data generation for shaders in cooked game (depends on the target platform rendering backend).

member.name: T:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings
member.summary: The navigation system settings container.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.CellHeight
member.summary: The height of a grid cell in the navigation mesh building steps using heightfields. A lower number means higher precision on the vertical axis but longer build times.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.CellSize
member.summary: The width/height of a grid cell in the navigation mesh building steps using heightfields. A lower number means higher precision on the horizontal axes but longer build times.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.TileSize
member.summary: Tile size used for Navigation mesh tiles, the final size of a tile is CellSize*TileSize.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MinRegionArea
member.summary: The minimum number of cells allowed to form isolated island areas.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MergeRegionArea
member.summary: Any regions with a span count smaller than this value will, if possible, be merged with larger regions.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MaxEdgeLen
member.summary: The maximum allowed length for contour edges along the border of the mesh.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MaxEdgeError
member.summary: The maximum distance a simplfied contour's border edges should deviate from the original raw contour.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.DetailSamplingDist
member.summary: The sampling distance to use when generating the detail mesh. For height detail only.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MaxDetailSamplingError
member.summary: The maximum distance the detail mesh surface should deviate from heightfield data. For height detail only.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.WalkableRadius
member.summary: The radius of the smallest objects to traverse this nav mesh. Objects can't pass through gaps of less than twice the radius.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.WalkableHeight
member.summary: The height of the smallest objects to traverse this nav mesh. Objects can't enter areas with ceilings lower than this value.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.WalkableMaxClimb
member.summary: The maximum ledge height that is considered to still be traversable.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.WalkableMaxSlopeAngle
member.summary: The maximum slope that is considered walkable (in degrees). Objects can't go up or down slopes higher than this value.

member.name: T:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings
member.summary: The physics simulation settings container. Allows to edit asset via editor.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.DefaultGravity
member.summary: The default gravity force value (in cm^2/s).

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.QueriesHitTriggers
member.summary: If enabled, any Raycast or other scene query that intersects with a Collider marked as a Trigger will returns with a hit. Individual raycasts can override this behavior.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.TriangleMeshTriangleMinAreaThreshold
member.summary: Triangles from triangle meshes (CSG) with an area less than or equal to this value will be removed from physics collision data. Set to less than or equal 0 to disable.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.BounceThresholdVelocity
member.summary: Minimum relative velocity required for an object to bounce. A typical value for simulation stability is about 0.2 * gravity

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.FrictionCombineMode
member.summary: Default friction combine mode, controls how friction is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.RestitutionCombineMode
member.summary: Default restitution combine mode, controls how restitution is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.DisableCCD
member.summary: If true CCD will be ignored. This is an optimization when CCD is never used which removes the need for PhysX to check it internally.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.EnableAdaptiveForce
member.summary: Enables adaptive forces to accelerate convergence of the solver. Can improve physics simulation performance but lead to artifacts.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.MaxDeltaTime
member.summary: The maximum allowed delta time (in seconds) for the physics simulation step.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.EnableSubstepping
member.summary: Whether to substep the physics simulation.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.SubstepDeltaTime
member.summary: Delta time (in seconds) for an individual simulation substep.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.MaxSubsteps
member.summary: The maximum number of substeps for physics simulation.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.LayerMasks
member.summary: The collision layers masks. Used to define layer-based collision detection.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.SupportCookingAtRuntime
member.summary: Enables support for cooking physical collision shapes geometry at runtime. Use it to enable generating runtime terrain collision or convex mesh colliders.

member.name: T:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush
member.summary: Terrain brush that has circle shape and uses radial falloff.

member.name: T:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffTypes
member.summary: Circle brush falloff types.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffTypes.Smooth
member.summary: A linear falloff that has been smoothed to round off the sharp edges where the falloff begins and ends.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffTypes.Linear
member.summary: A sharp linear falloff, without rounded edges.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffTypes.Spherical
member.summary: A half-ellipsoid-shaped falloff that begins smoothly and ends sharply.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffTypes.Tip
member.summary: A falloff with an abrupt start and a smooth ellipsoidal end. The opposite of the Sphere falloff.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.Falloff
member.summary: The brush falloff that defines the percentage from the brush's extents where the falloff should begin. Essentially, this describes how hard the brush's edges are. A falloff of 0 means the brush will have full effect throughout with hard edges. A falloff of 1 means the brush will only have full effect at its center, and the effect will be reduced throughout its entire area to the edge.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Tools.Terrain.Brushes.CircleBrush.FalloffType
member.summary: The brush falloff type. Defines circle brush falloff mode.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.AudioSource
member.summary: Represents a source for emitting audio. Audio can be played spatially (gun shot), or normally (music). Each audio source must have an AudioClip to play - back, and it can also have a position in the case of spatial(3D) audio.
member.remarks: Whether or not an audio source is spatial is controlled by the assigned AudioClip.The volume and the pitch of a spatial audio source is controlled by its position and the AudioListener's position/direction/velocity.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.summary: The audio clip asset used as a source of the sound.

member.summary: Gets the velocity of the source. Determines pitch in relation to AudioListener's position. Only relevant for spatial (3D) sources.

member.summary: Gets or sets the volume of the audio played from this source, in [0, 1] range.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Pitch

member.summary: Determines whether the audio clip should auto play on level start.

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum distance at which audio attenuation starts. When the listener is closer to the source than this value, audio is heard at full volume. Once farther away the audio starts attenuating.

member.summary: Gets or sets the attenuation that controls how quickly does audio volume drop off as the listener moves further from the source.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Asset.GetReferences
member.summary: Gets the asset references. Supported only in Editor.
member.remarks: For some asset types (e.g. scene or prefab) it may contain invalid asset ids due to not perfect gather method, which is optimized to perform scan very quickly. Before using those ids perform simple validation via Content cache API. The result collection contains only 1-level-deep references (only direct ones) and is invalid if asset is not loaded. Also the output data may have duplicated asset ids or even invalid ids (Guid.Empty).
member.returns: The collection of the asset ids referenced by this asset.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Content.Load(System.Guid,System.Double)
member.summary: Loads asset to the Content Pool and holds it until it won't be referenced by any object. Returns null if asset is missing. Actual asset data loading is performed on a other thread in async. The current thread execution is blocked until asset is loaded. Waits until asset will be loaded. It's equivalent to LoadAsync + WaitForLoaded.
member.returns: Asset instance if loaded, null otherwise

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.BoundingFrustum.GetZoomToExtentsShiftDistance(FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Get the distance which when added to camera position along the lookat direction will do the effect of zoom to extents (zoom to fit) operation, so all the passed points will fit in the current view. if the returned value is positive, the camera will move toward the lookat direction (ZoomIn). if the returned value is negative, the camera will move in the reverse direction of the lookat direction (ZoomOut).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPoint(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a point.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsRay(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPlane(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPlane(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Plane@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsTriangle(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.FloatR11G11B10
member.summary: Packed vector, layout: R:11 bytes, G:11 bytes, B:10 bytes. The 3D vector is packed into 32 bits as follows: a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for x component, a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for y component, a 5-bit biased exponent and a 5-bit mantissa for z. The z component is stored in the most significant bits and the x component in the least significant bits. No sign bits so all partial-precision numbers are positive. (Z10Y11X11): [32] ZZZZZzzz zzzYYYYY yyyyyyXX XXXxxxxx [0]

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.FloatR11G11B10.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the structure.
member.param: The floating point value that should be stored in R component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in G component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in B component (10 bits format).

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the structure.
member.param: The floating point value that should be stored in compressed format.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int2@,FlaxEngine.Int2@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int3@,FlaxEngine.Int3@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int3,FlaxEngine.Int3)

member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the matrix.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Invert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Transpose
member.summary: Transposes the matrix.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

When the method completes, contains the translation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.ReducedRowEchelonForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into reduced row echelon form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into reduced row echelon form.
The fifth column of the matrix.
When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.DecomposeQR(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into an orthonormalized Matrix3x3 q and a right triangular Matrix3x3 r.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the right triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.DecomposeLQ(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into a lower triangular Matrix3x3 l and an orthonormalized Matrix3x3 q.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the lower triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Decompose(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Quaternion@)
member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into a scale, rotation, and translation.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose an SRT transformation Matrix3x3 only.

member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector2[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector2[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation on an array of vectors using the given .
member.param: The array of coordinate vectors to transform.
The array for which the transformed vectors are stored. This array may be the same array as .
member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3[])

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector4@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.returns: The squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Assertions.Assert.AreApproximatelyEqual(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Asserts that the values are approximately equal. An absolute error check is used for approximate equality check (|a-b| < tolerance). Default tolerance is 0.00001f. Note: Every time you call the method with tolerance specified, a new instance of Assertions.Comparers.FloatComparer is created. For performance reasons you might want to instance your own comparer and pass it to the AreEqual method. If the tolerance is not specifies, a default comparer is used and the issue does not occur.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial
member.summary: Physical materials are used to define the response of a physical object when interacting dynamically with the world.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.Friction
member.summary: The friction value of surface, controls how easily things can slide on this surface.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.FrictionCombineMode
member.summary: The friction combine mode, controls how friction is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.OverrideFrictionCombineMode
member.summary: If set we will use the FrictionCombineMode of this material, instead of the FrictionCombineMode found in the Physics settings.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.Restitution
member.summary: The restitution or 'bounciness' of this surface, between 0 (no bounce) and 1 (outgoing velocity is same as incoming).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.RestitutionCombineMode
member.summary: The restitution combine mode, controls how restitution is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicalMaterial.OverrideRestitutionCombineMode
member.summary: If set we will use the RestitutionCombineMode of this material, instead of the RestitutionCombineMode found in the Physics settings.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect
member.summary: Custom postFx which can modify final image by processing it with material based filters. The base class for all post process effects used by the graphics pipeline. Allows to extend frame rendering logic and apply custom effects such as outline, night vision, contrast etc.
member.remarks: Override this class and implement custom post fx logic. Use MainRenderTask.Instance.CustomPostFx.Add(myPostFx) to attach your script to rendering. Or add script to camera.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.CanRender
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this effect can be rendered.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.UseSingleTarget
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether use a single render target as both input and output. Use this if your effect doesn't need to copy the input buffer to the output but can render directly to the single texture. Can be used to optimize game performance.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Location
member.summary: Gets the effect rendering location within rendering pipeline.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Order
member.summary: Gets the effect rendering order. Registered post effects are sorted before rendering (from the lowest order to the highest order).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Render(FlaxEngine.GPUContext,FlaxEngine.RenderContext@,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture)
member.summary: Performs custom postFx rendering.

member.summary: Gets timeScale-independent time in seconds it took to complete the last frame.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Time.UnscaledGameTime
member.summary: Gets timeScale-independent time at the beginning of this frame. This is the time in seconds since the start of the game.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Time.TimeSinceStartup
member.summary: Gets the time since startup in seconds (unscaled).

member.summary: Gets or sets the global density scale for all foliage instances. The default value is 1. Use values from range 0-1. Lower values decrease amount of foliage instances in-game. Use it to tweak game performance for slower devices.

member.summary: Gets the foliage type.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.AddFoliageType(FlaxEngine.Model)
member.summary: Adds the type of the foliage.
member.param: The model to assign. It cannot be null nor already used by the other instance type (it must be unique within the given foliage actor).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.RemoveFoliageType(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the foliage instance type and all foliage instances using this type.

member.summary: Gets the total amount of the instanced that use the given foliage type.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.AddInstance(FlaxEngine.FoliageInstance@)
member.summary: Adds the new foliage instance. Ensure to always call after editing foliage to sync cached data (call it once after editing one or more instances).
member.remarks: Input instance bounds, instance random and world matrix are ignored (recalculated).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.RemoveInstance(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the foliage instance. Ensure to always call after editing foliage to sync cached data (call it once after editing one or more instances).
member.param: The zero-based index of the instance to remove.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.SetInstanceTransform(System.Int32,FlaxEngine.Transform@)
member.summary: Sets the foliage instance transformation. Ensure to always call after editing foliage to sync cached data (call it once after editing one or more instances).
member.param: The zero-based index of the foliage instance.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.RebuildClusters
member.summary: Rebuilds the foliage clusters used as internal acceleration structures (quad tree).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.UpdateCullDistance
member.summary: Updates the cull distance for all foliage instances and for created clusters.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Foliage.Intersects(FlaxEngine.Ray@,System.Single@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Determines if there is an intersection between the current object or any it's child and a ray.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains the intersection surface normal vector (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains zero-based index of the foliage instance that is the closest to the ray.
member.returns: True whether the two objects intersected, otherwise false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.FeatureLevel
member.summary: Graphics feature levels indicates what level of support can be relied upon. They are named after the graphics API to indicate the minimum level of the features set to support. Feature levels are ordered from the lowest to the most high-end so feature level enum can be used to switch between feature levels (e.g. don't use geometry shader if not supported).

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage
member.summary: Identifies expected GPU resource use during rendering. The usage directly reflects whether a resource is accessible by the CPU and/or the GPU.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.Default
member.summary: A resource that requires read and write access by the GPU. This is likely to be the most common usage choice. Memory will be used on device only, so fast access from the device is preferred. It usually means device-local GPU (video) memory.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written and read by device, e.g. images used as render targets. - Resources transferred from host once (immutable) or infrequently and read by device multiple times, e.g. textures to be sampled, vertex buffers, constant buffers, and majority of other types of resources used on GPU.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.Dynamic
member.summary: A resource that is accessible by both the GPU (read only) and the CPU (write only). A dynamic resource is a good choice for a resource that will be updated by the CPU at least once per frame. Dynamic buffers or textures are usually used to upload data to GPU and use it within a single frame.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written frequently by CPU (dynamic), read by device. E.g. textures, vertex buffers, uniform buffers updated every frame or every draw call.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.StagingUpload
member.summary: A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the CPU to the GPU. It usually means CPU (system) memory. Resources created in this pool may still be accessible to the device, but access to them can be slow.
member.remarks: Usage: - Staging copy of resources used as transfer source.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.StagingReadback
member.summary: A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the GPU to the CPU.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written by device, read by host - results of some computations, e.g. screen capture, average scene luminance for HDR tone mapping. - Any resources read or accessed randomly on host, e.g. CPU-side copy of vertex buffer used as source of transfer, but also used for collision detection.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceMapMode
member.summary: Describes how a mapped GPU resource will be accessed.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceMapMode.Read
member.summary: The resource is mapped for reading.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceMapMode.Write
member.summary: The resource is mapped for writing.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceMapMode.ReadWrite
member.summary: The resource is mapped for reading and writing.

member.summary: Gets the additive rendering. Adds the color and the alpha channel. Source color is multiplied by the alpha.

member.summary: Gets the alpha blending.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend
member.summary: Blending mode.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Zero
member.summary: The blend factor is (0, 0, 0, 0). No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.One
member.summary: The blend factor is (1, 1, 1, 1). No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (Rs, Gs, Bs, As), that is color data (RGB) from a pixel shader. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrcColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Rs, 1 - Gs, 1 - Bs, 1 - As), that is color data (RGB) from a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (As, As, As, As), that is alpha data (A) from a pixel shader. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrcAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is ( 1 - As, 1 - As, 1 - As, 1 - As), that is alpha data (A) from a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.DestAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (Ad Ad Ad Ad), that is alpha data from a render target. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvDestAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Ad 1 - Ad 1 - Ad 1 - Ad), that is alpha data from a render target. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.DestColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad), that is color data from a render target. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvDestColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Rd, 1 - Gd, 1 - Bd, 1 - Ad), that is color data from a render target. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcAlphaSat
member.summary: The blend factor is (f, f, f, 1); where f = min(As, 1 - Ad). The pre-blend operation clamps the data to 1 or less.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.BlendFactor
member.summary: The blend factor is the blend factor set with GPUContext::SetBlendFactor. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.BlendInvFactor
member.summary: The blend factor is the blend factor set with GPUContext::SetBlendFactor. The pre-blend operation inverts the blend factor, generating 1 - blend_factor.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Src1Color
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources both as color data output by a pixel shader. There is no pre-blend operation. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrc1Color
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources both as color data output by a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Src1Alpha
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources as alpha data output by a pixel shader. There is no pre-blend operation. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrc1Alpha
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources as alpha data output by a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.summary: Stops current thread execution to gather buffer data from the GPU. Cannot be called from main thread if the buffer is not a dynamic nor staging readback.
member.returns: True if cannot download data, otherwise false.

member.summary: Gets the buffer data via map/memcpy/unmap sequence. Always supported for dynamic and staging readback buffers (other types support depends on graphics backend implementation).

member.summary: Sets the buffer data via map/memcpy/unmap sequence. Always supported for dynamic buffers (other types support depends on graphics backend implementation).

member.summary: Gets a CPU pointer to the resource by mapping its contents. Denies the GPU access to that resource.
member.returns: The pointer ot the mapped CPU buffer with resource data or null if failed.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.Unmap
member.summary: Invalidates the mapped pointer to a resource and restores the GPU's access to that resource.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain
member.summary: Material domain type. Material domain defines the target usage of the material shader.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Surface
member.summary: The surface material. Can be used to render the scene geometry including models and skinned models.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.PostProcess
member.summary: The post process material. Can be used to perform custom post-processing of the rendered frame.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Decal
member.summary: The deferred decal material. Can be used to apply custom overlay or surface modifications to the object surfaces in the world.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.GUI
member.summary: The GUI shader. Can be used to draw custom control interface elements or to add custom effects to the GUI.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Terrain
member.summary: The terrain shader. Can be used only with landscape chunks geometry that use optimized vertex data and support multi-layered blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Particle
member.summary: The particle shader. Can be used only with particles geometry (sprites, trails and ribbons). Supports reading particle data on a GPU.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode
member.summary: Material blending modes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Opaque
member.summary: The opaque material. Used during GBuffer pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Transparent
member.summary: The transparent material. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Additive
member.summary: The additive blend. Material color is used to add to color of the objects behind the surface. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Multiply
member.summary: The multiply blend. Material color is used to multiply color of the objects behind the surface. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel
member.summary: Material shading modes. Defines how material inputs and properties are combined to result the final surface color.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Unlit
member.summary: The unlit material. Emissive channel is used as an output color. Can perform custom lighting operations or just glow. Won't be affected by the lighting pipeline.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Lit
member.summary: The default lit material. The most common choice for the material surfaces.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Subsurface
member.summary: The subsurface material. Intended for materials like vax or skin that need light scattering to transport simulation through the object.

member.summary: The flag used to disable reflections. The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableDistortion
member.summary: The flag used to disable distortion effect (light refraction). The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags
member.summary: Material features usage flags. Detected by the material generator to help graphics pipeline optimize rendering of material shaders.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseMask
member.summary: Material is using mask to discard some pixels. Masked materials are using full vertex buffer during shadow maps and depth pass rendering (need UVs).

member.summary: The material is using emissive light.

member.summary: The material is using world position offset (it may be animated inside a shader).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseVertexColor
member.summary: The material is using vertex colors. The render will try to feed the pipeline with a proper buffer so material can gather valid data.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseNormal
member.summary: The material is using per-pixel normal mapping.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseDisplacement
member.summary: The material is using position displacement (in domain shader).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseRefraction

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.UpdateTriangles(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.UInt16})

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer0(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the first vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the second vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer2(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the third vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh has no vertex colors (stored in vertex buffer 2) the the returned value is null.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data or null if mesh has no vertex colors.

Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadIndexBuffer(System.Boolean)

Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],System.Int32[],FlaxEngine.Int4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Updates the skinned model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 32-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend indices buffer. Contains indices of the skeleton bones (up to 4 bones per vertex) to use for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend weights buffer (normalized). Contains weights per blend bone (up to 4 bones per vertex) of the skeleton bones to mix for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The normal vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],System.UInt16[],FlaxEngine.Int4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Updates the skinned model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 16-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend indices buffer. Contains indices of the skeleton bones (up to 4 bones per vertex) to use for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend weights buffer (normalized). Contains weights per blend bone (up to 4 bones per vertex) of the skeleton bones to mix for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The tangent vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat
member.summary: Enumeration with all pixel formats used by the graphics pipeline.
member.remarks: Reference: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb173059(v=vs.85).aspx

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.Unknown
member.summary: The format is not known.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32A32_Typeless
member.summary: A four-component, 128-bit typeless format that supports 32 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32A32_Float
member.summary: A four-component, 128-bit floating-point format that supports 32 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32A32_UInt
member.summary: A four-component, 128-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 32 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32A32_SInt
member.summary: A four-component, 128-bit signed-integer format that supports 32 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32_Typeless
member.summary: A three-component, 96-bit typeless format that supports 32 bits per color channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32_Float
member.summary: A three-component, 96-bit floating-point format that supports 32 bits per color channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32_UInt
member.summary: A three-component, 96-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 32 bits per color channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32B32_SInt
member.summary: A three-component, 96-bit signed-integer format that supports 32 bits per color channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_Typeless
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit typeless format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_Float
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit floating-point format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_UInt
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_SNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit signed-normalized-integer format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16B16A16_SInt
member.summary: A four-component, 64-bit signed-integer format that supports 16 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32_Typeless
member.summary: A two-component, 64-bit typeless format that supports 32 bits for the red channel and 32 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32_Float
member.summary: A two-component, 64-bit floating-point format that supports 32 bits for the red channel and 32 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32_UInt
member.summary: A two-component, 64-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 32 bits for the red channel and 32 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G32_SInt
member.summary: A two-component, 64-bit signed-integer format that supports 32 bits for the red channel and 32 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32G8X24_Typeless
member.summary: A two-component, 64-bit typeless format that supports 32 bits for the red channel, 8 bits for the green channel, and 24 bits are unused.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.D32_Float_S8X24_UInt
member.summary: A 32-bit floating-point component, and two unsigned-integer components (with an additional 32 bits). This format supports 32-bit depth, 8-bit stencil, and 24 bits are unused.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32_Float_X8X24_Typeless
member.summary: A 32-bit floating-point component, and two typeless components (with an additional 32 bits). This format supports 32-bit red channel, 8 bits are unused, and 24 bits are unused.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.X32_Typeless_G8X24_UInt
member.summary: A 32-bit typeless component, and two unsigned-integer components (with an additional 32 bits). This format has 32 bits unused, 8 bits for green channel, and 24 bits are unused.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R10G10B10A2_Typeless
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 10 bits for each color and 2 bits for alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R10G10B10A2_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format that supports 10 bits for each color and 2 bits for alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R10G10B10A2_UInt
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 10 bits for each color and 2 bits for alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R11G11B10_Float
member.summary: Three partial-precision floating-point numbers encoded into a single 32-bit value (a variant of s10e5, which is sign bit, 10-bit mantissa, and 5-bit biased (15) exponent). There are no sign bits, and there is a 5-bit biased (15) exponent for each channel, 6-bit mantissa for R and G, and a 5-bit mantissa for B.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_Typeless
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_UNorm_sRGB
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized integer sRGB format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_UInt
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_SNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit signed-normalized-integer format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8B8A8_SInt
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit signed-integer format that supports 8 bits per channel including alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_Typeless
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_Float
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit floating-point format that supports 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_UNorm
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format that supports 16 bits each for the green and red channels.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_UInt
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit unsigned-integer format that supports 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_SNorm
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit signed-normalized-integer format that supports 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R16G16_SInt
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit signed-integer format that supports 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32_Typeless
member.summary: A single-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 32 bits for the red channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.D32_Float
member.summary: A single-component, 32-bit floating-point format that supports 32 bits for depth.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32_Float
member.summary: A single-component, 32-bit floating-point format that supports 32 bits for the red channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32_UInt

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R32_SInt
member.summary: A single-component, 32-bit signed-integer format that supports 32 bits for the red channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R24G8_Typeless
member.summary: A two-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 24 bits for the red channel and 8 bits for the green channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.D24_UNorm_S8_UInt
member.summary: A 32-bit z-buffer format that supports 24 bits for depth and 8 bits for stencil.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R24_UNorm_X8_Typeless
member.summary: A 32-bit format, that contains a 24 bit, single-component, unsigned-normalized integer, with an additional typeless 8 bits. This format has 24 bits red channel and 8 bits unused.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.X24_Typeless_G8_UInt
member.summary: A 32-bit format, that contains a 24 bit, single-component, typeless format, with an additional 8 bit unsigned integer component. This format has 24 bits unused and 8 bits green channel.

member.summary: A single-component, 1-bit unsigned-normalized integer format that supports 1 bit for the red channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R9G9B9E5_SharedExp
member.summary: Three partial-precision floating-point numbers encoded into a single 32-bit value all sharing the same 5-bit exponent (variant of s10e5, which is sign bit, 10-bit mantissa, and 5-bit biased (15) exponent). There is no sign bit, and there is a shared 5-bit biased (15) exponent and a 9-bit mantissa for each channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8_B8G8_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format. This packed RGB format is analogous to the UYVY format. Each 32-bit block describes a pair of pixels: (R8, G8, B8) and (R8, G8, B8) where the R8/B8 values are repeated, and the G8 values are unique to each pixel. Width must be even.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.G8R8_G8B8_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format. This packed RGB format is analogous to the YUY2 format. Each 32-bit block describes a pair of pixels: (R8, G8, B8) and (R8, G8, B8) where the R8/B8 values are repeated, and the G8 values are unique to each pixel. Width must be even.

member.summary: If checked, bloom effect will be rendered.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Intensity
member.summary: Bloom effect strength. Value 0 disabled is, while higher values increase the effect.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Threshold
member.summary: Minimum pixel brightness value to start blowing. Values below the threshold are skipped.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.BlurSigma
member.summary: This affects the fall-off of the bloom. It's the standard deviation (sigma) used in the Gaussian blur formula when calculating the kernel of the bloom.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Limit
member.summary: Bloom effect brightness limit. Pixels with higher luminance will be capped to this brightness level.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings
member.summary: Contains settings for Tone Mapping effect rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.OverrideFlags
member.summary: The flags for overriden properties.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.WhiteTemperature
member.summary: Adjusts the white balance in relation to the temperature of the light in the scene. When the light temperature and this one match the light will appear white. When a value is used that is higher than the light in the scene it will yield a "warm" or yellow color, and, conversely, if the value is lower, it would yield a "cool" or blue color. The default value is `6500`.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.WhiteTint
member.summary: Adjusts the white balance temperature tint for the scene by adjusting the cyan and magenta color ranges. Ideally, this setting should be used once you've adjusted the white balance temporature to get accurate colors. Under some light temperatures, the colors may appear to be more yellow or blue. This can be used to balance the resulting color to look more natural. The default value is `0`.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.Mode
member.summary: The tone mapping mode to use for the color grading process.
